SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Dixon, Alfred Lyman
Present Address: Maple Creek, Sask.
Pioneer Address: Maple Creek, N.W.T.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1883

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 3 - 10

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 2

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Weekly.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Early days visited without invitations.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon, evenings.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Very seldom.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Potluck.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Lunch of crackers or cake with tea or coffee.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Very seldom whole family attended.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Ladies used to have quilt making activities for church or hospital.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. Small attendance of interested persons. 1895 - 1910.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Was brought up as a strict Methodist so did not attend social parties until after 1903. Was at parties or an odd home dance only.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. After 1900.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No.

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

Up to 1900 formality was attempted, but since then it became less formal.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Only in stories of Mounted Police, where members were most cases brought up that way.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

In early day had more games planned as musical chairs, charades, spelling matches, etc.

Recent year parties most case card playing.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

P.S. of Temperance.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

1895 for social temperance work.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes at present.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

This district is 75% ranching. Grain growers came here early 1890s but could not exist, but after 1899 had influx of farmers.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

75%

How many women belonged? 8

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

2.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Yes.

When was it organized? 1910.

Approximately how many women belonged to it? 20

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

In Town of Maple Creek. Stock Growers association rotated
Swift Current, Shaunavon, Bull Lake, Maple Creek.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

As above. Olden boys. Cricket. Football.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

22. What games did boys play in summer (jump rope, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

On above. Older boys played baseball.

What games did girls play in summer (jump rope, play house, etc.)?

On above. Tug - Pum - Shelfrun.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *As above.*

   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *Authors: Checkers - Chicken - Cribbage.*

   Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   *Yes, whole family in evenings.*

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *Evenings for short time*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   *Yes, tag.*

**PICNICS AND SPORTS.**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   *July - 1887.*

26. Who organized it?  
   *Methodist Sunday School.*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *Entire Community.*

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   *Yes, to knowledge.*

   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *Ball Games - races - Swings - Climbing Trees - Hills.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   *General lunch. Children served first.*

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *Sandwiches - Cookies - Cakes - Pie - Lemonade - Coffee.*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *In afternoon till nearing sundown.*

11. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

Free and easy time.

12. Describe any different kinds of places which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community places, school or Sunday School, places, family places, etc. Tell about any differences in matters attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Sunday School places.
Family places - usually not special arranged - had your own places. Popular places included.

13. What changes have you noticed in places since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Little better arranged from how clean, whole day.

14. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (sex, women, mostly young people).

All took part in early days, no numbers very much smaller in attendance.

15. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Curling - Polo.

What year? 1940 How long did it continue? 3-4 yrs

16. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1940, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

Lacrosse, softball, baseball.

17. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Curling and skating done on natural slushy. First skating rink built 1940.

Then was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Curling skating rink 1950. Used for hockey also.

Most of books were donated. Many in not too good repair & not able to finance a librarian's office. Books were supposed to be returned in 2 weeks.

MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
   Ans.: Got a piano about $80

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?
   Organs, Piano, Violins.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   Piano. But from ranchers who moved away do not know price paid.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
   Not very great. Usually had a sing song Sunday evenings by relatives and friends.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.
   Mostly sing songs. Occasional Musical Concerts. Very little group singing.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
   Church & School hymns.

in the community?
   The popular songs of the day.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.
   Not to any extent. Was very few instruments were in district. Not enough to take part.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
   No.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started? 1895.
   Who started it? Local farmers. How long did it continue? 7-8 yrs.
   After started school closed but it did not continue long due to lack of a leader.
   How many were in it? 15. Who was bandmaster? Don't remember.

What instruments were included?
   Popular band of brass.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
   Practiced regular. Did not have uniforms. Which played at several events with band concerts in summer.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Less important other than church choirs. Younger generation do not seem to have time for it.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

Have a few stamps not well kept. Have an old times museum in town I donate to it. It's open to public & have a nice selection. Keep a resident caretaker.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

No

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

No special hobbies. In early days did lot of horseback riding & often went out in evenings on riding party.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

Not to any extent

GENERAL
